newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian forward dlr premia ends down, may dip again.
newsitem.headline: Indian forward dlr premia ends down, may dip again.

text.p: The forward dollar premia ended sharply lower on Tuesday as a result of Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) weekend initiatives to boost liquidity and prompt a cut in lending rates, dealers said.
The forward dollar premia opened sharply lower, as was expected after the RBI's announcement on Saturday on cut in cash reserve ratio, releasing over 85 billion rupees to bank coffers.

April dollar opened at 1.33/1.38 rupees, sharply down from the weekend closing of 1.57/1.60 rupees. The closing rates were 1.30/1.34 rupees. The six month annualised premium was around 7.5 percent, down from the weekend closing of 8.5 percent.
"I feel this is the bottom," said a dealer at a foreign bank. "It's a good level for importers to enter."
A bank dealer said the forward dollar market saw at least 40 percent surge in volumes over the daily average on Tuesday.

"I feel this (premia of 7.5 percent) is the right level, on fundamentals," said Ranjit Shah, director at Su-Raj Diamonds, a leading exporting firm. "If corporates borrow at LIBOR plus one to 1.5 percentage point, it would be about 7.5 percent."
Shah said the average rupee borrowing cost of an Indian exporter was about 14 percent per annum. "The difference between this and LIBOR plus is about the same as the six month premium."
"Otherwise there would be arbitrage opportunities," he said.
But some dealers said the forward market could see lower premia in the days to come.
"I think 120 paise (1.20 rupees for April dollars) is the next level the market will aim," said Yeshwant Rao, deputy general manager (forex) at textile exporting firm Arvind Mills.
The rupee edged up against the dollar in the spot market.
The dollar closed at 35.6200/6250 rupees. The day opened at 35.66/69 rupees to a dollar but the rupee edged up immediately to 35.64/65 range on plentiful dollar supply, dealers said.
The chief dealer at a state-run bank said large dollar remittances, especially from the Middle East, accumulated over the weekend, helped the rupee's rise in the spot market.
"Some people had overbought dollars on the weekend, expecting large buying this week - this didn't happen," he said.
Dealers said the RBI did not buy dollars on Tuesday.
